month_1.gynecological_concerns: Confirm pregnancy, assess gestational age, rule out ectopic pregnancy, begin prenatal vitamins (folic acid), discuss lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, smoking cessation), schedule initial ultrasound, assess for any existing medical conditions.
month_1.tests: Urine pregnancy test, blood work (blood type, Rh factor, complete blood count, rubella titer, HIV, Hepatitis B and C, syphilis), ultrasound

month_2.gynecological_concerns: Monitor fetal heartbeat (around 6-8 weeks), assess for morning sickness, discuss potential complications, review diet and exercise plan, address any emotional concerns related to pregnancy.
month_2.tests: Ultrasound to confirm fetal heartbeat and viability

month_3.gynecological_concerns: Monitor weight gain, assess for any bleeding or cramping, discuss fetal development and milestones, advise on safe travel and work accommodations, screen for gestational diabetes.
month_3.tests: Ultrasound to assess fetal growth and development

month_4.gynecological_concerns: Fetal movement may begin to be felt, address concerns regarding quickening, continue monitoring weight gain, blood pressure and urine for protein, discuss options for childbirth education classes.
month_4.tests: Ultrasound to check fetal anatomy (often 18-22 weeks)

month_5.gynecological_concerns: Continue monitoring fetal movement, blood pressure, weight gain, address any concerns related to pregnancy discomforts (back pain, heartburn, swelling), discuss labor and delivery options.

month_6.gynecological_concerns: Continue monitoring fetal growth and well-being, discuss preparations for childbirth,  address any anxieties about labor and delivery.

month_7.gynecological_concerns: Monitor fetal position, assess for pre-term labor signs, discuss birthing plan, discuss breastfeeding preparation.
month_7.tests: Non-stress test (NST) and biophysical profile (BPP) may be started

month_8.gynecological_concerns: Continue monitoring fetal well-being, address any concerns about labor and delivery, discuss newborn care basics.

month_9.gynecological_concerns: Monitor for signs of labor, prepare for hospital admission, review birthing plan.

postpartum.pediatric_concerns: Assess newborn's health (APGAR score, weight, vital signs), initiate breastfeeding support, newborn screening tests,  address any newborn concerns (jaundice, feeding difficulties).
postpartum.gynecological_concerns: Postpartum bleeding assessment,  discuss recovery process (physical and emotional), contraception options, postnatal checkups.

presenting_complaint: Fatigue, shortness of breath, and mild chest discomfort for the past two weeks.

medical_history.hypertension: Diagnosed in 2016, currently managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily.
medical_history.hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed in 2020, currently on Atorvastatin 40mg daily.

family_history.father: Hypertension, deceased at 67 due to myocardial infarction.

social_history.occupation: Office Manager at a local financial firm.
social_history.exercise: Limited to light walking; reports sedentary lifestyle due to desk work.

physical_examination.general: Well-nourished, alert, oriented, no acute distress.
physical_examination.cardiovascular: S1, S2 heard clearly, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Peripheral pulses 2+ bilaterally. Mild edema noted in lower extremities.
physical_examination.respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezing, rales, or rhonchi.
physical_examination.abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present. No masses or organomegaly.
physical_examination.neurological: Cranial nerves II-XII intact. No focal neurological deficits. Strength 5/5 in all extremities.
physical_examination.musculoskeletal: No joint swelling or tenderness. Full range of motion in all extremities.

investigations.electrocardiogram_(ecg): Normal sinus rhythm, no signs of ischemia or previous infarct.
investigations.chest_x_ray: No acute pulmonary findings. Heart size within normal limits.

assessment: Hyperlipidemia, suboptimal response to current therapy

Exertional dyspnea with a history of smoking – likely secondary to cardiovascular risk factors. Differential diagnosis includes mild heart failure or early coronary artery disease, but more testing required.
plan: Adjust antihypertensive therapy: Increase Lisinopril to 40mg daily. Monitor blood pressure bi-weekly.
Continue Atorvastatin 40mg but reassess lipid levels in 6-8 weeks. Consider adding Ezetimibe if LDL levels remain high.
Order stress test and echocardiogram to further evaluate for underlying coronary artery disease or heart failure.

Lifestyle modifications: Encourage a heart-healthy diet (Mediterranean diet recommended). Increase daily physical activity with gradual introduction of light aerobic exercise. Counseling for weight loss with a target of 10% reduction over the next 6 months.
Follow-up: In 4 weeks for stress test results and reevaluation of hypertension.
